title: IS BANNING SOMEONE FROM A GAME WHERE THEY HAVE PURCHASED SOMETHING UNLAWFUL
body:
Hi, 
I would like to debate the fact that if you ban someone, ( btw i'm not banned ) from league of legends or any game were you can purchase addons or content without offering a refund as they can no longer use what they paid for through no fault of there own then couldn't this be a legal issue. as you are withholding a service after it has been paid for or purchased.? consumer laws state if you purchased something and the store can't give you said items or goods then they must refund you by banning someone who has paid for skins or in game content you are stopping them from using there purchases.

replies.body:
Short answer, no.

To begin with, RP has no monetary value, once you have converted real money into RP it loses that value. Money can = RP, RP does not = money.

Secondly, you agree to the ToS and the EULA every time there is a patch, which includes all the legal jibber jabber, but to sum it up, Riot owns the account. You are essentially loaning it from them indefinitely. It's the same principle as renting a house, if you break the rules you'll be kicked out with no refund for the rent you have paid in the past, however much or little that might be.
no under australian consumer law once you PAY MONEY for a good or service it MUST be supplied there eula is worthless here

The service has been supplied. You've exchanged your money for RP, that is the service provided. The ToS and EULA are different in OCE to comply with Australian and NZ consumer laws. Everything is legal. Again, once you've exchanged money for RP it loses it's monetary value and the service is supplied.

You do not own your account, Riot does, you only have access to it. To use the house analogy, you can't get kicked out of a house you own for something like noise complaints, you can only get fined/penalised, however if you rent a house and continually disturb neighbours and generally break rules the owner of the house has the right to kick you out.
but if i buy a skin to use and they forbid me to use said skin that infringes on the acl the eula was written for the USA and does not cover our acl as of january 2011

Again, the EULAs for NA and OCE are different. It does not infringe, you do not own the account or anything attached to it. You're welcome to take it up with a lawyer if you don't believe me, but they'll give you the same answer, Riot has done nothing wrong.

well i'm not a laywer yet but in my understanding of the law as a 2nd year student is that this paragraph in the eula constitutes a unfair contract under the ACL 

Game Assets, Riot Points and Virtual Items.  When using the Game, you may accumulate in-Game assets associated with your Account, including, without limitation, objects, artifacts,  items, equipment, and/or other value or status indicators (“Game Assets”) that reside on servers operated by Riot Games as data.  You acknowledge and agree that such Game Assets are accumulated as part of your Account and therefore you shall have no ownership or other property interest in any of those Game Assets.  You further acknowledge and agree that Riot Games has the right, but not the obligation, to delete, alter, move, remove, or transfer any and all Game Assets, in whole or in part, at any time and for any reason, with notice to you, and with no liability of any kind to you.  Riot Games does not provide or guarantee, and expressly disclaims any value, cash or otherwise, attributed to any data residing on servers operated by Riot Games, including without limitation the Game Assets associated with your Account.

How exactly is this an unfair contract? Again back to the house analogy. Even if you rent a furnished house, that furniture still doesn't belong to you, and you aren't going to be refunded for that rental cost, even assuming it was a one off payment when you first leased the house.

You do not own your account or anything on it, you pay for the right to use those features, not keep them.

Well if either of those two solicitors would like to sue Riot games I would appreciate to know how it goes. The consumer guarantees have exceptions, this being the important one:
https://www.accc.gov.au/consumers/consumer-rights-guarantees/consumer-guarantees
> Consumer guarantees do not apply if you:
> * misused a product in any way that caused the problem

The Eula and ToU  qualifies as a contract under Australian law and a player is not forced to enter it despite it being a requirement to play. As such breaking the ToU  is a violation of the contract on the consumer end. It's like those stickers on clothes that say "hand wash only" or "do not iron". You're free to ignore them, but it's your fault if the clothes are ruined.

The player gains access to the server/game in return for agreeing to do/not do certain things. Breaking that agreement qualifies as “misusing a product in a way that causes a problem”.

Here is my understanding of this situation.
Relevant laws and Documents: Australian Consumer Law "ACL", Riot Games Terms of Use "ToU", and Riot Games End User License Agreement "EULA".

Riot operates as a Service provider as no physical goods are purchased as a part of using the service.
When you sign up for an account, you are agreeing to a licensed access to the Service (the Game, Forum, basically any part that requires to be logged in). As a part of the license you may acquire the license to use In-Game Assets [ToU IV.b]. Since you are licensing the content, there is no transfer of ownership.
As for the suspension and/or termination of the Account, if a person violates either the ToU, EULA, or Code of Conduct then Riot has the right to suspend, terminate and/or deletion the Account as per ToU III.e.1, EULA VIII,IX. However Riot also reserves the right to enact any of these options at anytime at their discretion with or without notice. You also have the right to terminate the Account either by discontinuing use of the Account or by contacting Riot. This is not an unfair term as per ACL s24.1 as it is reasonably necessary to protect the legitimate interest of the party who would be advantaged by the term. In this case Riot protecting the interests of itself and other users in the advent of someone breaching the ToU. EULA, or Code of Conduct. 
If this was to be considered in court, the terms within the agreements are quite transparent and are keeping with the rest of the contract. 

So in summary: You are only licensing content from Riot and have no ownership of the content. Riot's ability to terminate individual agreements between you and Riot is allowed by law as you are also extended the same ability, making it a fair term.

To put it simply, unless you are purchasing the explicit right to not be banned the answer is no. Honestly, I've never heard of a game that allows it's players to pay money to not be banned, so you can be pretty confident that the answer will always be no.
